children.body: The provisions of this chapter control the height and area of structures hereafter erected and additions to existing structures.

The following terms are defined in Chapter 2:

AREA, BUILDING.

BASEMENT.

EQUIPMENT PLATFORM.

GRADE PLANE.

HEIGHT, BUILDING.

MEZZANINE.

diagrams.title: Group B or M Bldgs w/ Group S-2 Open Parking Garage Above
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The code provides a special provision to allow for vehicle parking to be placed above a place of business or retail. For the purpose of determining the type of construction, an S-2 open parking structure may be considered separately from a group B or M occupancy building below when all of the following conditions are met:
  1. A horizontal assembly of not less than 2 hours fire-resistance separates the two buildings
  2. The occupancy of the building below is limited to group B and M
  3. The occupancy of the building above is limited to a Group S-2 open parking garage
  4. The building below the horizontal assembly is of type IA construction. Exception: Where the building below is limited to 1 story in height the construction type for the lower building may be type IB or II but not less than the construction type required by the S-2 open parking garage above.
  5. The lower building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 503 (table 504).
  6. The upper building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 406.5. The height, in both feet and stories, shall be measured from grade plane and include the building below.
  7. Exits serving the garage discharge at grade with direct access to a street or public way and are separated from the building below by 2-hour fire barriers, 2-hour horizontal assemblies or both.

children.displayTitle: Section 503 General Building Height and Area Limitations
children.titleText: General Building Height and Area Limitations

children.body: Unless otherwise specifically modified in Chapter 4 and this chapter, building height, number of stories and building area shall not exceed the limits specified in Sections 504 and 506 based on the type of construction as determined by Section 602 and the occupancies as determined by Section 302 except as modified hereafter. Building height, number of stories and building area provisions shall be applied independently. Each portion of a building separated by one or more fire walls complying with Section 706 shall be considered to be a separate building.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls and Party Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Use of fire walls separating occupancies where fire separations using fire barriers are required are required to conform to the most restrictive items between the two. Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

diagrams.title: Single Bldgs. Divided by Fire Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In new construction, for the purposes of determining area limitations, height limitations and type of construction, each portion of a building separated by one or more fire walls complying with Section 706 shall be considered to be a separate building.

Where adopted, the Existing Building Code (IEBC) allows under very certain conditions the use of a fire barrier in lieu of a fire wall when there is a change of occupancy for lower hazard uses. Frequently, it would be very difficult to provide a fully code compliant fire wall in many of these situations.

diagrams.title: Mezzanine Area Example - Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A mezzanine is a portion of a story that is located within a room and is considered a part of the story below. It does not contribute to the building area or the number of stories in the building. Mezzanines must comply with specific regulations outlined in the Building Code, such as the clear height above and below the mezzanine floor construction being not less than 7 feet (Section 505.2). Additionally, the area of the mezzanine is included in determining the fire area (Section 505.2).

children.body: Buildings and structures designed to house special low-hazard industrial processes that require large areas and unusual building heights to accommodate craneways or special machinery and equipment, including, among others, rolling mills; structural metal fabrication shops and foundries; or collection and treatment of sewage and stormwater, or the production and distribution of electric, gas or steam power, shall be exempt from the building height, number of stories and building area limitations specified in Sections 504 and 506. Ordinary repairs of such buildings or structures shall include specifically engineered structural and mechanical components designed for removal and replacement in kind.

Two or more buildings on the same lot shall be regulated as separate buildings or shall be considered as portions of one building where the building height, number of stories of each building and the aggregate building area of the buildings are within the limitations specified in Sections 504 and 506. The provisions of this code applicable to the aggregate building shall be applicable to each building.

diagrams.title: Buildings on the Same Lot (Ex. 1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.3 outlines the requirements for adding a separate building to a site that already contains an existing building. To apply this section correctly, an understanding of fire separation distances and fire separation lines is necessary. The designer must establish a fire separation line on the site that aligns with the exterior wall and opening protectives of the existing building. Once this line is defined, the new building can be designed as if this line is a property line. Exception 1 permits the new and existing buildings to be treated as a single structure, thereby eliminating the fire separation protections required by the imaginary fire separation line in the base condition.

Exception 1 limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type present on the site.

Exception 2 applies when an S-2 parking garage of Type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. This exception allows for zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage. However, 1-1/2 hour fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with Section 706.8, which limits the size of single openings and the total width of openings relative to the wall length.

children.body: Buildings of Type I construction permitted to be of unlimited tabular building heights and areas are not subject to the special requirements that allow unlimited area buildings in Section 507 or unlimited building height in Sections 503.1.1 and 504.3 or increased building heights and areas for other types of construction.

diagrams.title: Building Height on Sloping Site
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When a site is sloping, the grade plane will likely be at a location different than the story level of the "first floor". So, simply adding the floor to floor heights and the final floor to average roof height may not provide an accurate measurement of the building height.

First, determine the location of grade plane, as a fixed location with a datum (such as elevation above sea level). Then, using the definition of "Story Above Grade Plane", determine if the story in question is either the Story Above Grade Plane, or a basement. The difference between the level of the floor of the Story Above Grade Plane will have to be either added to or subtracted from the building height, measured from the floor of the Story Above Grade Plane to determine an accurate building height measured from grade plane.

Story Above Grade Plane: Any story having its finished floor surface entirely above grade plane, or in which the finished surface of the floor next above is:

1. More than 6 feet (1829 mm) above grade plane; or
2. More than 12 feet (3658 mm) above the finished ground level at any point.

A number of code requirements are measured from grade plane. Basements are defined as not being a story above grade plane. Even though allowable building height in stories is measured from grade plane, care should be exercised in determining whether or not the story considered at grade level is indeed a "story above grade plane" which should be included in the allowable number of stories.

children.displayTitle: Section 504 Building Height and Number of Stories
children.titleText: Building Height and Number of Stories

children.body:
The height, in feet, and the number of stories of a building shall be determined based on the type of construction, occupancy classification and whether there is an automatic sprinkler system installed throughout the building.
Exception: The building height of one-story aircraft hangars, aircraft paint hangars and buildings used for the manufacturing of aircraft shall not be limited where the building is provided with an automatic sprinkler system or automatic fire-extinguishing system in accordance with Chapter 9 and is entirely surrounded by public ways or yards not less in width than one and one-half times the building height.

diagrams.title: Type IIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIA ("Two-A") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "A" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are required to be fire-rated construction.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Type IIB Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIB ("Two-B") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "B" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are not required to be fire-rated construction. Exceptions may exist, such as walls close to a property line or a neighboring building.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Area Aircraft Bldgs.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The height of the single story aircraft hangar, or aircraft paint hangar is unlimited if the building is equipped with an automatic fire sprinkler or suppression system.

diagrams.title: Type IIIB Const.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

Significant exceptions exist in Section 602.3 for buildings of certain occupancies and in fire districts.

diagrams.title: Type IIIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing and sheathing complying with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

children.body: The height of unlimited area buildings shall be designed in accordance with Section 507.

diagrams.title: Open Spaces for Unlimited Area Bldgs.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The proper way to measure required yard space is from the perimeter of the building to the lot line, or face of another building on the same lot. A public way is measured for the entire width of the public way, not just for the portion of the building that fronts the public way.

children.body: The special provisions of Section 510 permit the use of special conditions that are exempt from, or modify, the specific requirements of this chapter regarding the allowable heights of buildings based on the occupancy classification and type of construction, provided the special condition complies with the provisions specified in Section 510.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Parking Beneath Group R
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.4 allows for the increase of one story above a Type I closed/open garage or Type IV open garage with a horizontal assembly with a fire resistive rating equal to that of 508.4 or the required type of construction, whichever is greater. Section 406.5.3 allows open parking garages complying with 510.4 to be mixed use occupancies. Depending on the other occupancy groups below the R occupancy it is possible areas could require a greater fire-resistance rating than is required for the type of construction.

Some literature suggests that a lesser rating can be applied to the floor of type IV construction. However, the wording of the code section does not seem to provide that option. Heavy timber construction for floors is based on a prescriptive size of wood members. Mass timber construction requires a minimum floor rating of 2 hours, and only footnote a of Table 601 allows for reduction of ratings of a floor rating. It does not appear the code allows for reduction of the floor rating to 1 hour, as some suggest.

The user should also be aware that starting with the 2021 year edition, sections of 903.3.1.2 more severely restricts the use of NFPA 13R systems for this condition to the grade plane, instead of the horizontal assembly above the garage.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Type IIIA Height Increases
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 510.5 is a variation on the idea of a horizontal separation to allow for increased building height for a specific building type. For Type III-A, R-1/R-2 buildings that provide compartmentalization by means of fire walls, increased height is permitted. Fire walls should extend all the way to the basement. The horizontal separation is for a specific use and is not used to create two separate buildings, as Section 510.2 does.

children.body: In a building containing mixed occupancies in accordance with Section 508, no individual occupancy shall exceed the height and number of story limits specified in this section for the applicable occupancies.

diagrams.title: Allowable Height Above Grade Plane
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The allowable building height is measured from grade plane. If the average roof height, measured from grade plane, is less than the height from grade, then the building will comply. In this case, a Type II-B building with an NFPA 13 sprinkler system and with a Group B occupancy is on a sloping site. Since the average roof height is 61 feet above grade plane, and the maximum allowable height is 75 feet, then the building will comply.

diagrams.title: Structural Member Protection At High Ceilings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
According to Table 601, Footnote b, except in Group F-1, H, M and S-1 occupancies, fire protection of structural members in roof construction shall not be required, including protection of primary structural frame members, roof framing and decking where every part of the roof construction is 20 feet or more above any floor immediately below. Fire-retardant-treated wood members shall be allowed to be used for such unprotected members. However, be aware the 2015 codes does not include the term "primary structural frame members".

UpCodes Note: Primary structural members include columns per the definition. However, per an interpretation on June 22, 2018, regarding the 2018 codes, ICC staff opined that the columns were not part of the fire rating exemption provided by Table 601, footnote b. Per Section 704, if columns are required to be fire rated, the protection is required to extend to its connection with other structural members. Please check with your local AHJ concerning the interpretation of this issue in your locality.

If an accessible route is required to connect stories within a building or facility, the accessible route must serve all mezzanines.

diagrams.title: Guards:  Connection Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
ASCE 7 requires the 200 pound load to be placed in any direction at any point on the handrail or top rail to produce a maximum load effect. This would mean a load pulling on the rail inward would create a maximum tension on the bottom bolt, but a 200 pound force outward (typically associated with "falling" outward) would put the maximum tension on the top bolt.

However, the Residential Code, in Table R301.5, footnote d, states: "A single concentrated load applied in any direction at any point along the top. For a guard not required to serve as a handrail, the load need not be applied to the top element of the guard in a direction parallel to such element." This language does not seem to appear in ASCE 7 at this time.

Therefore, the designer should consider providing tension resisting hardware on both bolts, or consider an alternate design. Simply relying on the rim board would put the member into cross-grain bending, which has considerably lower strength than the beam itself.

diagrams.title: Guards: Where Required
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Wherever there is an open-sided walking area that is more than 30" above the floor level (out to 36" where the ground may slope or be uneven), the walkway requires a guard rail to be in place. There are certain spaces where a guard requirement would not be practical or possible, these areas are exempt from this requirement and include stages and performing areas, truck loading docks, and vehicle servicing pits. Assembly seating areas do not need to comply with this section, but rather, must comply with the guard requirements of Section 1029.17.2. Glass and glazing materials are permitted for use as a guard, however they must meet the performance and strength requirements of sections 2407 and 1607.8 of the building code. Where the glazing does not meet these strength and resistance requirements, guards are required to be installed along with of the glazing.

diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.3 outlines the requirements for adding a separate building to a site that already contains an existing building. To apply this section correctly, an understanding of fire separation distances and fire separation lines is necessary. The designer must establish a fire separation line on the site that aligns with the exterior wall and opening protectives of the existing building. Once this line is defined, the new building can be designed as if this line is a property line. Exception 1 permits the new and existing buildings to be treated as a single structure, thereby eliminating the fire separation protections required by the imaginary fire separation line in the base condition.

Exception 1 limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type present on the site.

Exception 2 applies when an S-2 parking garage of Type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. This exception allows for zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage. However, 1-1/2 hour fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with Section 706.8, which limits the size of single openings and the total width of openings relative to the wall length.

diagrams.title: Type IIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIA ("Two-A") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "A" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are required to be fire-rated construction.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Type IIB Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIB ("Two-B") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "B" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are not required to be fire-rated construction. Exceptions may exist, such as walls close to a property line or a neighboring building.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Type IIIB Const.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:

Fire-retardant-treated wood framing with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

Significant exceptions exist in Section 602.3 for buildings of certain occupancies and in fire districts.

diagrams.title: Non Separated vs. Separated Occ.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The use of separated and non-separated occupancies is two of the three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

Non-separated occupancies offer more open planning options and reduced wall construction, but come at the cost of treating the entire building (or portion thereof) as the most restrictive occupancy group. This affects not only allowable area and height, but also fire protection features—especially under Chapter 9, where sprinkler requirements, fire alarms, and smoke control systems must meet the higher standard across the board. From an implementation standpoint, non-separated occupancies are simpler to document but more limiting for maximizing usable area, particularly when integrating high-intensity uses like Assembly (Group A-3) with lower-risk uses like Business (Group B).

Separated occupancies require rated fire barriers and/or rated horizontal assemblies between different occupancy groups per Section 508.4. In addition the structural systems supporting these barriers must also themselves be rated. This introduces complexity in detailing, cost, and coordination across MEP penetrations and egress paths. However, this separation allows each occupancy to retain its own allowable area, height, and fire protection approach, often resulting in better yield for multi-use buildings.

Non-separation of occupancy groups does not eliminate the need for fire ratings related to specific features, such as corridors, control areas, shafts, an atrium, two-story openings, etc. In these situations, the specific code requirements for separations must be used even if the overall building is considered non-separated, as the separation is a condition of the specific feature, such as an atrium or opening between levels (See Section 712.1.9).

Similarly, "separation" is only recognized where a rated assembly is continuous and properly detailed—meaning partial separations, stub walls, or incomplete barriers do not count toward code compliance. Architects must engage early with code consultants and AHJs to align expectations, especially when pursuing performance-based design or leveraging exceptions (e.g., Section 510 for podium construction or control areas for hazardous materials) that can further complicate occupancy separations.

Exception 1 permits the new and existing buildings to be treated as a single structure, thereby eliminating the fire separation protections required by the imaginary fire separation line in the base condition.

Exception 1 limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type present on the site.

Exception 2 applies when an S-2 parking garage of Type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. diagrams.title: Nonseparated Occupancies 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Nonseparated occupancies use the most restrictive area per story for the sprinkler system chosen for determining if the building meets allowable area. The total building area must also be checked and the ratio of total building area to allowable area (based on the most restrictive) must be less than 3.0 (or 2.0 for two stories and for certain occupancy groups in California).

Even though a nonseparated occupancy may meet the area and height requirements, occupancy separations are required in certain situations such as H or R occupancies regardless. Also, the required floor/ceiling and structural ratings must also be met for the type of construction chosen.

Further limitations on building height or area must also be checked against the Life Safety Code when applicable to a project based on the use (i.e. Medical, Business, etc).

diagrams.title: Nonseparated Occupancies 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Nonseparated occupancies use the most restrictive area per story for the sprinkler system chosen for determining if the building meets allowable area. The total building area must also be checked and the ratio of total building area to allowable area (based on the most restrictive) must be less than 3 (or 2, for two stories and certain occupancy groups in California).

Even though a nonseparated occupancy may meet the area and height requirements, occupancy separations are required in certain situations such as H or R occupancies regardless. Also, the required floor/ceiling and structural ratings must also be met for the type of construction chosen.

Further limitations on building height or area must also be checked against the Life Safety Code when applicable to a project based on the use (i.e. Medical, Business, etc).

diagrams.title: Separated Occupancies 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Separated occupancies check the sum of the ratios of designed-to-allowable areas for each story to determine if the building meets allowable area. The total building area must also be checked and the sum of the ratios of each story must be less than 3.0 (or 2.0 for two stories and for certain occupancy groups in California). diagrams.title: Non Separated vs. Separated Occ.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The use of separated and non-separated occupancies is two of the three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

Non-separated occupancies offer more open planning options and reduced wall construction, but come at the cost of treating the entire building (or portion thereof) as the most restrictive occupancy group. This affects not only allowable area and height, but also fire protection features—especially under Chapter 9, where sprinkler requirements, fire alarms, and smoke control systems must meet the higher standard across the board. From an implementation standpoint, non-separated occupancies are simpler to document but more limiting for maximizing usable area, particularly when integrating high-intensity uses like Assembly (Group A-3) with lower-risk uses like Business (Group B).

Separated occupancies require rated fire barriers and/or rated horizontal assemblies between different occupancy groups per Section 508.4. In addition the structural systems supporting these barriers must also themselves be rated. This introduces complexity in detailing, cost, and coordination across MEP penetrations and egress paths. However, this separation allows each occupancy to retain its own allowable area, height, and fire protection approach, often resulting in better yield for multi-use buildings.

Non-separation of occupancy groups does not eliminate the need for fire ratings related to specific features, such as corridors, control areas, shafts, an atrium, two-story openings, etc. In these situations, the specific code requirements for separations must be used even if the overall building is considered non-separated, as the separation is a condition of the specific feature, such as an atrium or opening between levels (See Section 712.1.9).

Similarly, "separation" is only recognized where a rated assembly is continuous and properly detailed—meaning partial separations, stub walls, or incomplete barriers do not count toward code compliance. Architects must engage early with code consultants and AHJs to align expectations, especially when pursuing performance-based design or leveraging exceptions (e.g., Section 510 for podium construction or control areas for hazardous materials) that can further complicate occupancy separations.

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Intervening Spaces/Accessory Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Cumulative occupant loads affect egress design when occupants must pass through shared or intervening spaces en route to an exit. When multiple rooms discharge through a common space, that space must be designed to accommodate the total number of occupants that pass through it—not just its own occupant load.

This approach ensures the egress system is appropriately sized for actual use conditions. However, it's important to understand that this requirement applies only to the occupants who traverse the shared path. If a space has multiple exit routes and some occupants do not use the intervening area, only those who do contribute to the cumulative load at that point. This avoids artificially inflating the required egress capacity by counting occupants twice.

Architects should take care during the early planning stages to analyze not just the occupant load of rooms, but also the actual flow of occupants during egress, tracing how people move through space and identifying bottlenecks. It's especially important in open or hybrid layouts—such as coworking areas, medical offices, or tenant spaces within larger occupancies—where paths of travel may be shared or split. Misinterpreting who contributes to the cumulative load can lead to over- or under-designing critical egress components, affecting code compliance and occupant safety.

Accessory occupancies are part of the mixed occupancy provisions to allow small amounts of spaces that are used by other parts of the same space but not count against them in regards to allowable area calculations. They may be used in combination with separated and non-separated occupancy provisions. For example, an office in a retail establishment, or a small conference room in a large office space.

The two spaces on the left, because they support (and have some sort of spacial connection to the main space), are ancillary; therefore, they can be "Accessory occupancies". Tenant space #2 is separate, does not support the tenant #1 space, nor is it connected. Therefore, it is not ancillary and cannot likely be an accessory occupancy. If a space supports a main space, but is not directly connected, the design professional should make a determination if this is an appropriate accessory occupancy designation.

diagrams.title: Non Separated vs. Separated Occ.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The use of separated and non-separated occupancies is two of the three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

Non-separated occupancies offer more open planning options and reduced wall construction, but come at the cost of treating the entire building (or portion thereof) as the most restrictive occupancy group. This affects not only allowable area and height, but also fire protection features—especially under Chapter 9, where sprinkler requirements, fire alarms, and smoke control systems must meet the higher standard across the board. From an implementation standpoint, non-separated occupancies are simpler to document but more limiting for maximizing usable area, particularly when integrating high-intensity uses like Assembly (Group A-3) with lower-risk uses like Business (Group B).

Separated occupancies require rated fire barriers and/or rated horizontal assemblies between different occupancy groups per Section 508.4. In addition the structural systems supporting these barriers must also themselves be rated. This introduces complexity in detailing, cost, and coordination across MEP penetrations and egress paths. However, this separation allows each occupancy to retain its own allowable area, height, and fire protection approach, often resulting in better yield for multi-use buildings.

Non-separation of occupancy groups does not eliminate the need for fire ratings related to specific features, such as corridors, control areas, shafts, an atrium, two-story openings, etc. In these situations, the specific code requirements for separations must be used even if the overall building is considered non-separated, as the separation is a condition of the specific feature, such as an atrium or opening between levels (See Section 712.1.9).

Similarly, "separation" is only recognized where a rated assembly is continuous and properly detailed—meaning partial separations, stub walls, or incomplete barriers do not count toward code compliance. Architects must engage early with code consultants and AHJs to align expectations, especially when pursuing performance-based design or leveraging exceptions (e.g., Section 510 for podium construction or control areas for hazardous materials) that can further complicate occupancy separations.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire rated wall assemblies are of three varieties: fire walls, fire barriers and fire partitions. Fire barriers can be used as shaft enclosures, occupancy separations and others. Fire partitions are often used as demising walls and corridor separations, among other uses.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Private Garage Separation from Dwelling Units (BC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because the garage is a motor vehicle related occupancy there are special requirements in the code. Section 406.3.2 specifically addresses the fire separation and protection requirements for a private garage that is constructed directly adjacent to or as part of a dwelling unit. The garage is required to be separated from the dwelling unit and its attic area by means of gypsum board, not less than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) in thickness, applied to the garage side. If there is a habitable room located above the garage, then a 5/8-inch Type X gypsum board or equivalent and 1/2-inch gypsum board separation is required on the garage side where the condition exists. Structural elements in the garage supporting the habitable spaces will also require 1/2-inch gypsum board separation.

Example: A post or a wall in the garage that supports a habitable floor above the garage space will require 1/2-inch gypsum board separation. The code then goes on to define door opening requirements for openings between a private garage and a dwelling unit. The leaf itself shall be constructed of either solid wood doors or solid or honeycomb core steel doors not less than 1-3/8 inches in thickness, or doors in compliance with Section 716.2.2.1 with a fire protection rating of not less than 20 minutes. The door is required to be self-closing, this need is typically accomplished w/ spring loaded hinges or a door closer. The door is also required to be self-latching, and this is typically accomplished by the use of an appropriate lockset. Ducts located in the garage and ducts that penetrate walls or ceilings that separate the dwelling unit including the attic spaces from the garage are required to be constructed of sheet steel of not less than 0.019 inch (0.48 mm) in thickness and shall not have openings into the garage.

The height and area of the garage is dictated by section 406.5. The height and area of the building above is determined by section 503, includes the height and stories of the garage and is measured from grade plane. The two buildings need to be separated by fire barriers or horizontal assemblies with fire resistance ratings per Table 508.4 for the two uses. 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire barriers or horizontal assemblies are required to separate the means of egress for the upper building from the garage.

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses: Laundry Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Laundry rooms over 100 sf in area are considered an incidental use. Per Table 509.1 they must be separated from the rest of the building by 1 hour fire rated construction and be protected by an automatic sprinkler system. Laundry rooms that are part of and serve and individual dwelling unit do not require any separation or protection.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage Beneath Groups A, I, B, M and R
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a group A, I, B, M or R building is above an Open Parking Garage the allowable height and area for the building above and the garage are determined by different sections of the code. The height and area of the garage is dictated by section 406.5. The height and area of the building above is determined by section 503, includes the height and stories of the garage and is measured from grade plane. The two buildings need to be separated by fire barriers or horizontal assemblies with fire resistance ratings per Table 508.4 for the two uses. 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire barriers or horizontal assemblies are required to separate the means of egress for the upper building from the garage.

diagrams.title: Group S-2 Enclosed Parking Garage With Group S-2 Open Parking Garage Above
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A Group S-2 enclosed parking garage with no more than one story above grade plane, located beneath a Group S-2 open parking garage, is considered a separate building for construction type purposes if the following conditions are met:
  • The sum of area actual area to allowable area ratios of both occupancies must not exceed 1;
  • The enclosed garage is of type I or II construction and has equal or greater fire resistance than required for the open parking garage;
  • The open garage complies with height and tier limits in Table 406.5.4;
  • The floor assembly separating the two types of garages must meet the enclosed garage's fire protection requirements;
  • Openings other than exit openings between the two garage types are not required to be protected;
  • And the enclosed garage must be used solely for private vehicle parking or storage.
An accessory use area up to 1000 sf that may contain an office, waiting room, and toilet room is allowed in the enclosed garage. The enclosed garage may also contain a mechanical room that serves the building.

diagrams.title: Group B or M Bldgs w/ Group S-2 Open Parking Garage Above
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The code provides a special provision to allow for vehicle parking to be placed above a place of business or retail. For the purpose of determining the type of construction, an S-2 open parking structure may be considered separately from a group B or M occupancy building below when all of the following conditions are met:
  1. A horizontal assembly of not less than 2 hours fire-resistance separates the two buildings
  2. The occupancy of the building below is limited to group B and M
  3. The occupancy of the building above is limited to a Group S-2 open parking garage
  4. The building below the horizontal assembly is of type IA construction. Exception: Where the building below is limited to 1 story in height the construction type for the lower building may be type IB or II but not less than the construction type required by the S-2 open parking garage above.
  5. The lower building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 503 (table 504).
  6. The upper building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 406.5. The height, in both feet and stories, shall be measured from grade plane and include the building below.
  7. Exits serving the garage discharge at grade with direct access to a street or public way and are separated from the building below by 2-hour fire barriers, 2-hour horizontal assemblies or both.

children.body: The provisions in Sections 510.2 through 510.9 shall permit the use of special conditions that are exempt from, or modify, the specific requirements of this chapter regarding the allowable building heights and areas of buildings based on the occupancy classification and type of construction, provided the special condition complies with the provisions specified in this section for such condition and other applicable requirements of this code. The provisions of Sections 510.2 through 510.8 are to be considered independent and separate from each other.

A building shall be considered as separate and distinct buildings for the purpose of determining area limitations, continuity of fire walls, limitation of number of stories and type of construction where all of the following conditions are met:
  1. The buildings are separated with a horizontal assembly having a fire-resistance rating of not less than 3 hours.
  2. The building below the horizontal assembly is of Type IA construction.
  3. Shaft, stairway, ramp and escalator enclosures through the horizontal assembly shall have not less than a 2-hour fire-resistance rating with opening protectives in accordance with Section 716.5.
    Exception: Where the enclosure walls below the horizontal assembly have not less than a 3-hour fire-resistance rating with opening protectives in accordance with Section 716.5, the enclosure walls extending above the horizontal assembly shall be permitted to have a 1-hour fire-resistance rating, provided:
    1. The building above the horizontal assembly is not required to be of Type I construction;
    2. The enclosure connects fewer than four stories; and
    3. The enclosure opening protectives above the horizontal assembly have a fire protection rating of not less than 1 hour.
  4. The building or buildings above the horizontal assembly shall be permitted to have multiple Group A occupancy uses, each with an occupant load of less 300, or Group B, M, R or S occupancies.
  5. The building below the horizontal assembly shall be protected throughout by an approved automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, and shall be permitted to be any occupancy allowed by this code except Group H.
  6. The maximum building height in feet (mm) shall not exceed the limits set forth in Section 504.3 for the building having the smaller allowable height as measured from the grade plane.

diagrams.title: NFPA 13R: Where Permitted
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Use of NFPA 13R sprinklers are limited to R occupancies and may severely limit the allowed height and/or number of stories, especially if also required to be in compliance with the Life Safety Code (NFPA 101) or the 2018 based building codes, even if used in a podium condition.

diagrams.title: Single Bldgs. Divided by Fire Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In new construction, for the purposes of determining area limitations, height limitations and type of construction, each portion of a building separated by one or more fire walls complying with Section 706 shall be considered to be a separate building.

Where adopted, the Existing Building Code (IEBC) allows under very certain conditions the use of a fire barrier in lieu of a fire wall when there is a change of occupancy for lower hazard uses. Frequently, it would be very difficult to provide a fully code compliant fire wall in many of these situations.

diagrams.title: Multiple Buildings Above a Horizontal Assembly
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The buildings above a Group S-2 parking garage or other building may be regarded as separate and distinct buildings from each other when separated from the building below by a horizontal assembly in accordance with the special provisions of Sections 510.2, 510.3 or 510.8.

children.body:
A Group S-2 enclosed parking garage with not more than one story above grade plane and located below a Group S-2 open parking garage shall be classified as a separate and distinct building for the purpose of determining the type of construction where all of the following conditions are met:
  1. The allowable area of the building shall be such that the sum of the ratios of the actual area divided by the allowable area for each separate occupancy shall not exceed 1.
  2. The Group S-2 enclosed parking garage is of Type I or II construction and is at least equal to the fire-resistance requirements of the Group S-2 open parking garage.
  3. The height and the number of tiers of the Group S-2 open parking garage shall be limited as specified in Table 406.5.4.
  4. The floor assembly separating the Group S-2 enclosed parking garage and Group S-2 open parking garage shall be protected as required for the floor assembly of the Group S-2 enclosed parking garage. Openings between the Group S-2 enclosed parking garage and Group S-2 open parking garage, except exit openings, shall not be required to be protected.
  5. The Group S-2 enclosed parking garage is used exclusively for the parking or storage of private motor vehicles, but shall be permitted to contain an office, waiting room and toilet room having a total area of not more than 1,000 square feet (93 m2) and mechanical equipment rooms incidental to the operation of the building.

children.body: Where a maximum one story above grade plane Group S-2 parking garage, enclosed or open, or combination thereof, of Type I construction or open of Type IV construction, with grade entrance, is provided under a building of Group R, the number of stories to be used in determining the minimum type of construction shall be measured from the floor above such a parking area. The floor assembly between the parking garage and the Group R above shall comply with the type of construction required for the parking garage and shall also provide a fire-resistance rating not less than the mixed occupancy separation required in Section 508.4.

diagrams.title: NFPA 13R: Where Permitted
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Use of NFPA 13R sprinklers are limited to R occupancies and may severely limit the allowed height and/or number of stories, especially if also required to be in compliance with the Life Safety Code (NFPA 101) or the 2018 based building codes, even if used in a podium condition.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Parking Beneath Group R
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.4 allows for the increase of one story above a Type I closed/open garage or Type IV open garage with a horizontal assembly with a fire resistive rating equal to that of 508.4 or the required type of construction, whichever is greater. Section 406.5.3 allows open parking garages complying with 510.4 to be mixed use occupancies. Depending on the other occupancy groups below the R occupancy it is possible areas could require a greater fire-resistance rating than is required for the type of construction.

Some literature suggests that a lesser rating can be applied to the floor of type IV construction. However, the wording of the code section does not seem to provide that option. Heavy timber construction for floors is based on a prescriptive size of wood members. Mass timber construction requires a minimum floor rating of 2 hours, and only footnote a of Table 601 allows for reduction of ratings of a floor rating. It does not appear the code allows for reduction of the floor rating to 1 hour, as some suggest.

The user should also be aware that starting with the 2021 year edition, sections of 903.3.1.2 more severely restricts the use of NFPA 13R systems for this condition to the grade plane, instead of the horizontal assembly above the garage.

children.body: The height limitation for buildings of Type IIIA construction in Groups R-1 and R-2 shall be increased to six stories and 75 feet (22 860 mm) where the first floor assembly above the basement has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 3 hours and the floor area is subdivided by 2-hour fire-resistance-rated fire walls into areas of not more than 3,000 square feet (279 m2).

diagrams.title: Fire Walls and Party Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Use of fire walls separating occupancies where fire separations using fire barriers are required are required to conform to the most restrictive items between the two. Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Type IIIA Height Increases
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 510.5 is a variation on the idea of a horizontal separation to allow for increased building height for a specific building type. For Type III-A, R-1/R-2 buildings that provide compartmentalization by means of fire walls, increased height is permitted. Fire walls should extend all the way to the basement. The horizontal separation is for a specific use and is not used to create two separate buildings, as Section 510.2 does.

diagrams.title: Type IIIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing and sheathing complying with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

children.titleText: Group R-1 and R-2 Buildings of Type IIIA Construction

children.body: The height limitation for buildings of Type IIA construction in Groups R-1 and R-2 shall be increased to nine stories and 100 feet (30 480 mm) where the building is separated by not less than 50 feet (15 240 mm) from any other building on the lot and from lot lines, the exits are segregated in an area enclosed by a 2-hour fire-resistance-rated fire wall and the first floor assembly has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 11/2 hours.

diagrams.title: Group R-1 & R-2 Bldgs Type IIA - Height Increase Pt 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code provides for special provisions for additional height and number of stories when additional fire protection measures as prescribed by the code are provided. For group R-1 and R-2 buildings of type IIA construction the height limitations may be increased to 9 stories and 100 feet when the following additional fire protection measures are part of the design. The fire separation distance to all lot lines or to any other building on the lot must be not less than 50". The exits from each floor must also be segregated from each other in an area enclosed by a 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire wall. The first floor assembly must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1-1/2 hours. Per 704.1 any structure supporting the first floor assembly would likewise also need to have the same 1-1/2 hour fire protection rating.

diagrams.title: Group R-1 & R-2 Bldgs Type IIA - Height Increase Pt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code provides for special provisions for additional height and number of stories when additional fire protection measures as prescribed by the code are provided. For group R-1 and R-2 buildings of type IIA construction the height limitations may be increased to 9 stories and 100 feet when the following additional fire protection measures are part of the design. The fire separation distance to all lot lines or to any other building on the lot must be not less than 50". The exits from each floor must also be segregated from each other in an area enclosed by a 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire wall. The first floor assembly must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1-1/2 hours.

Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

diagrams.title: Type IIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIA ("Two-A") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "A" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are required to be fire-rated construction.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

children.body: Open parking garages constructed under Groups A, I, B, M and R shall not exceed the height and area limitations permitted under Section 406.5. The height and area of the portion of the building above the open parking garage shall not exceed the limitations in Section 503 for the upper occupancy. The height, in both feet and stories, of the portion of the building above the open parking garage shall be measured from grade plane and shall include both the open parking garage and the portion of the building above the parking garage.

children.body: Fire barriers constructed in accordance with Section 707 or horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711 between the parking occupancy and the upper occupancy shall correspond to the required fire-resistance rating prescribed in Table 508.4 for the uses involved. The type of construction shall apply to each occupancy individually, except that structural members, including main bracing within the open parking structure, which is necessary to support the upper occupancy, shall be protected with the more restrictive fire-resistance-rated assemblies of the groups involved as shown in Table 601. Means of egress for the upper occupancy shall conform to Chapter 10 and shall be separated from the parking occupancy by fire barriers having not less than a 2-hour fire-resistance rating as required by Section 707 with self-closing doors complying with Section 716 or horizontal assemblies having not less than a 2-hour fire-resistance rating as required by Section 711, with self-closing doors complying with Section 716. Means of egress from the open parking garage shall comply with Section 406.5.

Group B or M occupancies located below a Group S-2 open parking garage of a lesser type of construction shall be considered as a separate and distinct building from the Group S-2 open parking garage for the purpose of determining the type of construction where all of the following conditions are met:
  1. The buildings are separated with a horizontal assembly having a fire-resistance rating of not less than 2 hours.
  2. The occupancies in the building below the horizontal assembly are limited to Groups B and M.
  3. The occupancy above the horizontal assembly is limited to a Group S-2 open parking garage.
  4. The building below the horizontal assembly is of Type IA construction.
    Exception: The building below the horizontal assembly shall be permitted to be of Type IB or II construction, but not less than the type of construction required for the Group S-2 open parking garage above, where the building below is not greater than one story in height above grade plane.
  5. The height and area of the building below the horizontal assembly does not exceed the limits set forth in Section 503.
  6. The height and area of the Group S-2 open parking garage does not exceed the limits set forth in Section 406.5. The height, in both feet and stories, of the Group S-2 open parking garage shall be measured from grade plane and shall include the building below the horizontal assembly.
  7. Exits serving the Group S-2 open parking garage discharge directly to a street or public way and are separated from the building below the horizontal assembly by 2-hour fire barriers constructed in accordance with Section 707 or 2-hour horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both.
